abstract.p: Joseph Smith letter responds to July 13 news article on fatal fuel pipeline explosion in Niger Delta; contends the 1,500 deaths in similar accidents since last year serve as grim reminder of high social costs incurred from oil exploration in remote regions (M)

block.p: The latest deaths in a fuel pipeline explosion in the Niger Delta (news article, July 13) are a grim reminder of the high social costs incurred from oil exploration in remote regions. In Nigeria, 1,500 deaths had occurred since last year in tragedies similar to the current one.

The Nigerian government and oil companies blame vandals for the line breaks, but other contributing factors include the use of substandard piping by oil companies and the inability of the Nigerian government to enforce safety codes.

The latest deaths in a fuel pipeline explosion in the Niger Delta (news article, July 13) are a grim reminder of the high social costs incurred from oil exploration in remote regions. In Nigeria, 1,500 deaths had occurred since last year in tragedies similar to the current one.

The Nigerian government and oil companies blame vandals for the line breaks, but other contributing factors include the use of substandard piping by oil companies and the inability of the Nigerian government to enforce safety codes.
Endemic poverty also contributes; impoverished villagers flock to line breaks to collect fuel. Any accidental spark can mean instant mass death.

Last month, the World Bank approved a large oil pipeline project in the neighboring countries of Cameroon and Chad. The continuing tragedy of oil-led development in the Niger Delta should serve as a cautionary reminder of the devastating effect of such policy initiatives on the lives of the powerless.
